subclusters.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Protein Quality Control and Mitophagy Theory
Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Protein Quality Control and Mitophagy Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on mitochondrial quality control mechanisms including proteases, chaperones, and mitophagy to maintain mitochondrial integrity and prevent aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Protein Quality Control and Mitophagy Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Emphasizes mitochondrial small heat shock proteins (chaperones) that maintain mitochondrial proteostasis and link stress resistance to lifespan.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Protein Quality Control and Mitophagy Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes mitochondrial protein quality control systems (chaperones, proteases) and their decline with age as drivers of mitochondrial dysfunction and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Protein Quality Control and Mitophagy Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on mitophagy induction via SKN-1/Nrf2 pathway as a key mitochondrial quality control mechanism that delays aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Centers on mitochondrial ROS production causing oxidative damage and a self-amplifying vicious cycle leading to aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Highlights mitochondrial ROS generation, oxidative damage to lipids and proteins, and decline in antioxidant defenses as aging drivers.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on mitochondrial free radical production causing mtDNA damage, respiratory chain decline, and cellular heterogeneity in aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Emphasizes mtDNA damage accumulation from free radicals impairing oxidative phosphorylation and driving systemic aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes mitochondrial free radical production and how caloric restriction reduces ROS generation to retard aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Details oxidative damage accumulation to mtDNA, proteins, and lipids from mitochondrial ROS causing mitochondrial decay and aging.
Focuses on accumulation of mtDNA mutations causing mitochondrial failure, increased ROS, and a vicious cycle accelerating aging.
Describes high mtDNA mutation rate, clonal expansion in postmitotic cells, and resulting biochemical defects driving aging.
Emphasizes inherited and somatic mtDNA mutations causing bioenergetic decline and ROS-mediated damage accelerating aging.
Links mtDNA mutation accumulation to NAD+ depletion, UPRmt activation, and stem cell exhaustion causing intestinal aging.
Focuses on mtDNA mutation accumulation causing bioenergetic crisis, mitochondrial apoptosis, and tissue degeneration in aging.
Shows somatic mtDNA mutations cause respiratory chain dysfunction in bone cells, linking mtDNA mutation accumulation to systemic aging.
Describes mtDNA defects causing respiratory chain dysfunction and metabolic imbalances beyond free radicals driving aging.
Focuses on mitochondrial damage accumulation, oxidative stress, and genetic regulation of mitochondrial aging pathways influencing lifespan.
Emphasizes ETC dysfunction, ROS production, and adaptive responses modulating lifespan and aging across tissues and species.
Describes mitochondrial functional decline, oxidative stress, mtDNA mutations, and membrane alterations impairing bioenergetics in aging.
Links mitochondrial dysfunction and ROS accumulation induced by intermittent hypoxia and HIF-1 signaling to accelerated aging.
Focuses on mitonuclear epistasis modulating mitochondrial function, rapamycin response, and age-specific mortality affecting aging.
Describes age-related decline in mitochondrial energy utilization efficiency, compensatory mitochondrial density increase, and oxidative damage.
Focuses on reversible mitochondrial oxidative stress regulatory inhibition causing skeletal muscle dysfunction and rapid functional restoration.
